Award.AwardTitle: Interdisciplinary Workshop on Statistical Natural Language Processing Methods for Software Engineering

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: This grant funds a workshop to bring together two communities: Software Engineering and Natural Language Processing. Statistical natural language processing (NLP) techniques and tools have become very powerful and are applicable in many domains. Software Engineering researchers have begun to to adopt NLP techniques and tools in the context of Software Engineering to analyze repositories of source code as if they were natural language artifacts. The purpose of this grant is to bring together the Software Engineering and Natural Language communities to address these problems. Many Software Engineering processes and products involve natural language artifacts, such as requirements documents and code comments, and peer reviews, which play a role in program comprehension, code search, traceability and many other purposes in the software development process. The workshop will accelerate the pace of Software Engineering research in these areas and beyond. Natural Language researchers will identify new research directions stimulated by challenges in the Software Engineering domain. Natural Language can be a mode of communication to assist disabled such as people who are visually impaired and or have muscular injuries, thus one of the broader impacts is to advance research that would make programming tasks and jobs more accessible to those populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to help create and enliven a new, interdisciplinary community of researchers interested in applying statistical, NLP, and machine learning methods to the increasingly large collection of software source code. 

WIth this funding a series of workshops were held, and support provided to attendees. 

The first of these workshops was co-sponsored by Microsoft, which provided logistical support (venue, coffee, meals, transportation and banquet). The event was held in Fall 2015 at the Redmond campus. The event lasted 2 days, with a preceeding half-day dedicated to tutorials on NLP for Se researchers (by Dr Ashish Vaswani) and SE for NLP researchers (by prof. Tao Xie). Videos of all talks were recorded, and have been made available by Microsoft. 

The second workshop in the series was held in conjunction with ACM SIGSOFT FSE 2016, also in Seattle Washington. A third workshop was held at AAAI 2018, in New Orleans. Although this was the last where attendees were sponsored by NSF, the series has continued, with one to be held next week in ACM SIGSOFT 2018 at Orlando, FL. 

The workshops have succeed in creating a community of researchers. The field is thriving. Well-nigh 400 papers have now been published, in conferences including FSE, ICSE, PLDI, POPL, AAAI, and ICLR. There are several startups working in teh area, and major software companies, including Microsoft and Facebook have products based on these ideas that are in active use. 

As a result of contacts made during the workshops, and specifically, a tutorial prepared by Dr Miltos Allamanis of Microsoft Research, an ACM Computing Surveys article has been written and published, just this year. It already has 30+ citations. 

This is an exciting, active, growing field, already realized in some products, and with tremendous future potential. The community is grateful to NSF for helping kick-start this field.
